For instance, he was advised to pay the judgment debt and follow up with the appropriate proceedings, and when it came to the appropriate proceedings he was advised that he should not have paid the judgment debt in the first place. It would seem at times that his counsel was working for the other side. When Keith Smith witnessed Sweeney's signature, he was not to know that it was going to cost him almost $36,000 all up.

Given that National Australia Bank is the most profitable bank in Australia, it is worth reflecting on its arrogance and the way that it has no doubt trampled on the lives of others like Keith Smith to make its billion-dollar-plus profit a year. Keith is a war service pension recipient. He deserves better. Our nation deserves better from one of our largest corporations. The NAB has acted like thugs in this case. Perhaps NAB's performance was based more on the fact that, should Keith Smith be given the dignity he deserves, the floodgates would open as other claims are made.

This is an old story, going back almost 15 years. The NAB will have a go at me for raising it again today, but it is a matter that keeps on coming back. That Keith Smith has lived a horrible life over the last 15 years and that his family have suffered is a matter that I personally will not forget. I have known Keith for about 11 years. I first highlighted this story when I was working as a journalist at Channel 7, and I am pleased to have the opportunity to raise it again here in the House of Representatives today.

talk.start.para: —One of the issues causing great concern in Australia and in the communities I represent is the impact of privatisation—or, should I say, the sale of government assets.

speech.para: This government has an ideological commitment to privatising anything and everything. Unfortunately, this type of unconditional ideological commitment does not take into account the effect that privatisation has on the lives of Australian workers, families, pension ers and those people in our society who need a little bit of extra assistance. Unlike those on the other side of this House, I believe that the only things privatisation guarantees Australians are increased costs, decreased and inferior services and massive job losses. It is no longer about providing a quality user-friendly service to the people of Australia; rather, it is about companies making a profit.

One of the most interesting aspects of privatisation is that governments sell only those assets that are profitable and returning a good dividend. We do not hear about the government selling those things that are returning losses or things that are great drains on government. In other words, if you have a government business and it is making an enormous profit, particularly if that business is a monopoly or has a very large share of the market, then this government believes it should be sold. If this is coupled with deregulation, then there is the potential for a very dangerous situation to develop—a situation where vital services are controlled by a small private sector and where few restrictions are placed on the providers of these services and often the only regulation is self-regulation or industry regulation, and I believe that that is not strong enough.

There are numerous examples of this negative impact. One of the most visible currently is the banking industry. This is an industry where there is no public service provider and where the government refuses to regulate to protect consumers. Time and time again in this House we have heard the government say that it is not going to be involved. The government believes that the protection is there—I do not.

The sale of the electricity industry in Victoria is another good example. It has had an enormous impact on the communities and the people living in that state. Since the industry was privatised there has been an increase in service charges. Every service costs more and every service must be paid for. There have been massive job losses in the industry. Almost an entire work force has been dislocated. This in turn has created enormous problems within the community, with businesses failing, family breakdowns, domestic violence increasing, along with problems with gambling and alcohol abuse—all the types of things that happen in communities that are under severe pressure.

Along with the increase in the cost of service, there is a decrease in service provision. Since the privatisation in Victoria, there has been an enormous increase in the number of brownouts and blackouts. The time taken to restore the services or address the problems that have been caused by these brownouts and blackouts is getting longer and longer, and the number of staff there to deal with those problems is insufficient. This is the legacy of privatisation: poor service, increased costs and massive job loss.

My latest concern about privatisation is this government's move towards fully privatising Telstra. It would appear that this government's philosophical and ideological commitment to privatisation blinds it to the impact of the sale of government assets and blinds it to the impact that privatisation has on the people in Australia. The Howard government's move to further privatise Telstra is a disgrace and does not have the support of the majority of Australians—the people who will be the losers with further privatisation.

During the last election, the privatisation of Telstra was a major issue within the Shortland electorate and, during that time, thousands of people signed petitions protesting any further sale of Telstra—petitions that I will be presenting to this House. The Howard government's move to further privatise Telstra is a blatant disregard of the voices of the people of Australia. It is a disgrace and does not have the support of the majority of people.

Services to customers have already been slashed. Telstra's equipment and assets have deteriorated, with maintenance and asset renewal being secondary to profit. This is reflected in the fact that, when the people of Shortland and other areas throughout Australia ring Telstra to lodge a complaint, there are long delays before their needs and problems are addressed. There have been enormous job losses in Telstra, with many thousands of other jobs being earmarked to go in the future. It is no wonder people have to wait days for services that they received in hours before the partial privatisation.

My electorate office in Shortland has been inundated with complaints about Telstra services and the moves to further privatise Telstra. The people who ring the office are real people with real problems—problems that affect their lives and, in some cases, even place their lives at risk. The partially privatised Telstra, with its reduced number of employees, is unable to maintain the high quality of service that the people of Australia have come to expect from Telstra over the years. People constantly contact my office and complain about waiting for long periods to have their telephone services connected or reconnected or to receive even the most basic service.

Last week, a young mother spoke to me about her problem. She has a young baby and her phone was disconnected on Tuesday. She was advised that there was a problem with the line and it took until Thursday before her service was restored. This was a young woman with a very young baby. She is a person who relies on the telephone to contact doctors, her family and all the support services she has out there in the community. Her situation is not unusual because this is happening on a daily basis. Young families, elderly people and the sick are left without vital telephone services because Telstra cannot meet the needs of its clients since the partial privatisation. It is just not good enough. I have been advised that there is a shortage of lines in the Hunter and Central Coast area—the area that I represent. This shortage of lines is having an enormous impact on the people waiting to have their telephone services connected.

Last week, I received complaints about this from a number of people. One family in particular come to mind. They had moved house and did not immediately have the telephone connected. This was because they were a little short of finances after the move and they had to balance their budget. They were very much aware of the restrictions their finances placed on them. There was a telephone sitting in the house, but they waited for three or four weeks and then they rang Telstra and said, `We've got the money now. We would like the telephone connected.' Telstra said, `Sorry. We allocated your line to someone else. Unfortunately, you now have to wait and, when one does become available, you're going to have to pay for it.' This family were most distraught.

They rang my office and said, `We've already been waiting two weeks. Can you do something to help us?' We spoke to Telstra and tried to sort out the problem, but it is a problem that families are facing throughout Australia today. It is a problem that will get worse and worse if Telstra is fully privatised. It is just not good enough. The lack of lines and the problems that people are facing really demonstrate that there is no forward planning; it is just a reactive approach. If people want a service, then they have to pay for it. Everything that they get, they must pay for.

Telstra has obviously opted completely out of the planning process. It has opted out of everything that does not relate to making a profit. This reflects the direction in which it is going and the priorities it has. It reflects the fact that service is no longer the thing that is important. If we go further down the privatisation line, it will only affect ordinary everyday Australians—people who rely on Telstra to live in a safe environment, people who rely on Telstra for their contact with the outside world and people who need the valuable services that Telstra has provided over the years. This is a service that people in Australia for many years have come to expect as a quality service, a service that will be there; it is not something they should be provided with if there is an enormous profit going to the company. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I did not intend to start in this vein, but I have just heard the member for Shortland come forth with another stream of forgetfulness. I cannot understand what has happened to all my friends on the opposition benches. Are they all suffering from a mass memory loss, or do they think the people of Australia are dills? Since this parliament has resumed, we have had a stream of opposition members who have been carrying on about privatisation, attacking the government about privatisation, and their memories are completely defective and faulty. Have they forgotten about Qantas? Have they forgotten about the Commonwealth Bank?
—No.

—I am delighted to hear from my friend that they have not forgotten. He is the only one who has got a working memory, because the rest have forgotten. What have they kept saying? `The Liberal and National parties have been carried away with an ideological commitment to privatisation.'

speech.para: The people of Australia remember that the Labor Party said they would not sell all of the Commonwealth Bank, and then they went ahead and did it. And they sold all of Qantas. People have not forgotten that, unlike our sale of one-third of Telstra which mainly went to getting rid of debt, they did not pay off a single dollar of debt. It is like somebody with a farm who is in big trouble with the mortgage. They sell the back paddock but, instead of paying off the mortgage, paying off the debt, they take it all down to the pub and drink it. That is what Labor have done.

I am sick to death of people on my right coming in and wailing, whingeing and whining about the government's ideological commitment to selling things. When we do it, we do it for the good of Australia and we use the money to pay off the debt of all Australians. And that is worth doing.

I have one final point to make on this subject. The member for Shortland suggested that we never did anything, sold anything or wanted to sell anything if it were not making vast profits. Obviously she does not know about the ANL, which the Labor Party when in government wanted to sell as well. That was not making a profit, and we are delighted that we managed to sell it, even though the member for Kingsford-Smith at the time said it was unsaleable—and that destroyed their sale. We should also not forget that the then Labor government appointed Neville Wran and Mr Turnbull to try to sell it for a fee of $600,000. Enough of that, but I say to my friends on the other benches: get your memories working and cut out this pious whingeing and whining about what we are doing when you did exactly the same—you just frittered the money away.

I want to talk immediately about a lady who, regrettably, is no longer with us. I am talking about Mrs Enda Dotti, who was an Aboriginal elder in Kempsey in the Macleay Valley and a wonderful woman. I am privileged that, over the years that I have been in this place, she and I became very good friends indeed. We both had a high degree of affection for each other. If people want to talk about reconciliation, that is the best form of reconciliation.

As I have said countless times, the `p' in politics stands for `people'. When we talk about reconciliation between white Australia and Aboriginal Australia, we have to start talking about people too. I deeply regret that Enda is no longer with us, and I convey my condolences to her children and her family. She was a great woman. She was a great Australian. She worked tirelessly for Aboriginal people and reconciliation in the real way, which is not political fighting but getting on with the job of being people.

I would also like to speak about a young gentleman, a young boy, Jake Skelly, who is seven years of age and lives in Urunga. Since the age of nine months, he has suffered from chronic renal failure, which totally stunts the growth of affected children. But, for the past two years, his quality of life has surged dramatically because he has been treated with a growth hormone. It has changed his life totally. In that period, his weight has gone up by 10 kilograms and his height has increased by 20 centimetres. Unfortunately, this drug will supposedly be removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme from 1 January.

The family has two other children and, of course, if Jake's access to the growth hormone which has changed his life is removed, the family will have to find $7,000 a year for the treatment that he needs. You cannot put a dollar value on life. You cannot put a dollar value on the quality of life. The reality is that, within our society—people in need, people with health problems—the community spends far more than that, and I just want to appeal to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to reconsider this.

Of course, it is not only Jake. Throughout Australia there are 60 kids suffering from this disease. In Jake's case, ultimately he will receive, I hope, a kidney transplant. He will certainly need one when he is older. But the reality is that this growth hormone has made such a major impact. He has not only grown in height and put on weight, he is now a member of the local surf club as a nipper and he has joined the swimming club. This is a young Australian who has found life through the growth hormone. If it is removed, he will certainly lose that quality of life.

I would also like to talk about a road in my electorate, the Point Plomer Road, that runs between Crescent Head and the north shore of Port Macquarie. So what, you may say. I see the member for Barton and I am about to tell him that it is a very important road to the future of the Macleay Valley and the Hastings Valley. As we progress with the Pacific Highway, the town of Kempsey will receive a bypass, a deviation. One of the things that people are concerned about when a major highway which currently goes through the town—which is a negative really because the queues at Christmas are kilometres long—is to be bypassed is the effect on their commercial survival. The people of Kempsey are right to ponder that.

I would like to make a suggestion. We should get the Kempsey Shire Council and the Hastings Municipal Council together with the state and federal government. If we can seal the Point Plomer Road—which runs right along the coast, along those beautiful beaches, through national parks—we will have one of the best one-day tourist drives in the whole of Australia. It will enable the Macleay Valley and the people of Kempsey to tap into the tourism numbers of Port Macquarie. It will provide Port Macquarie with an additional feature for their visitors.

If they drove from Port Macquarie to Kempsey, they could inspect Akubra, one of the most amazing manufacturing places that you will see. Perhaps we could get an Aboriginal keeping place in Kempsey as well and then they could proceed out to the coast and travel by the Point Plomer Road back to Port Macquarie to the north shore. There is no bridge across, which many of the residents of the north shore really want, but ferries are a means of transport that is presently used. Providing the people of the north shore of Port Macquarie were not disadvantaged by such action and were not pushed out of the link, bigger ferries could be put on. I am sure that that is possible.

The ordinary people from the electorates of Barton, Scullin or New England would regard a ride across the river on a car ferry as very interesting and exciting. It is something that they never see these days. I would like to urge those two local government bodies—the state government and our own government—to get together and do something about getting this going.

I would also like to talk about the need for funding for the City Hill Art Gallery in Coffs Harbour. We have had a very hardworking committee going now for 10 or maybe 12 years. City Hill is an area that was originally going to be used for welfare housing, but Tom Uren, when he was Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, stepped in and made sure that it could be sold to the Coffs Harbour City Council and it would be the site of a major cultural centre. We need an art gallery. We already have the Bunker Cartoon Gallery, which is a great success, but the city council, by itself, will not have the funds to actually proceed with the development.

The design for the art gallery has been drawn, the scale models are there. It has actually won an architectural award for design excellence. So I say to the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation that we have a distinct and definite need in Coffs Harbour, in the electorate of Cowper, for funding to enable the regional art gallery to be built for the benefit of not just Coffs Harbour but the whole region.

talk.start.para: —Protection of our heritage is the responsibility of all of us. It will only be achieved through a partnership of government—local, state and federal—and the community. So yesterday I was pleased to attend a German Heritage Fest at Westgarthtown in my electorate. The first thing the Consul-General to Melbourne from the Republic of Germany—who had only been here a couple of weeks—did on being invited to Westgarthtown was to look up in the Melways where Westgarthtown was. Of course, Westgarthtown does not survive as a modern suburb of Melbourne. Westgarthtown is in the area of Lalor and Thomastown.

speech.para: The importance of a German Heritage Fest, of course, is that much has been written about the German immigration to South Australia but less is known about the immigration from Germany to Port Phillip directly, before the gold rush and before Victoria's colonial separation from New South Wales. Some of these German settlers settled on a 640-acre tract of land known as Westgarthtown, purchased for them by the prominent Melbourne merchant William Westgarth, in Thomastown. Westgarth had encouraged German immigration to Port Phillip because he had seen the South Australian Germans and was impressed with their `industry, frugality, sobriety and general good conduct' which had made them excellent colonists. The point about Westgarthtown was that these select migrants from German and Wendish families came together to establish a Lutheran settlement and, using their Lutheran beliefs, common farming and dairying practices and a hardworking ethic, set out to build that settlement. It was appropriate that yesterday, during the 150th anniversary of German immigration to Victoria and amongst the bricks of modern Thomastown suburbia, people were able to come together amongst the original bluestone buildings that still stand as evidence of the earlier German-Wendish presence to celebrate that connection in historical terms. It was a great celebration not only for the local community but for the wider German community of the state of Victoria.

The Westgarthtown settlement as we know it today has been absorbed into the suburbs of Thomastown and Lalor, but in the 1980s it was declared a historical precinct. Robert Wuchatsch in his book Westgarthtown: The German Settlement at Thomastown quotes the comments made by one of those who adjudicated on the suitability for listing, Dr Miles Lewis of the University of Melbourne's School of Architecture, who wrote in his report to the National Trust that Westgarthtown was:
. . . one of Victoria's most distinctive ethnic settlements, reflecting the historical circumstances of settlement, German vernacular building traditions, and the geology and conditions of the area.

Today, at Westgarthtown, several very important buildings survive. Ziebell's farmhouse, barn and outhouse survive. They are in the ownership of the City of Whittlesea. There is the Lutheran cemetery and the Lutheran Church. Then there are Graff's homestead and Siebel's homestead, which are still in private ownership. Lastly, there is Wuchatsch farmhouse, which is in private ownership and still inhabited by the descendants of the original settlers.

Whilst these buildings have been preserved and the larger area—including Ziebell's farmhouse, the cemetery and the church—was the centre of the activities yesterday, today I grieve that there is another building which is suffering great neglect. That building is Maltzahn's farmhouse. It went into the ownership of the Victorian ministry of housing back in the late 1980s. Up until then, it had been inhabited by several different families who were related to the original Wendish settlers of the area.

At that time, the ministry of housing applied to build nine dwellings. They applied for a permit back in 1992, and the City of Whittlesea Council decided to issue the permit against some objections. The fundamental reason for deciding to support the proposal was of course that there would be community benefit because the heritage building itself would be refurbished. Whilst the dwellings were built by the ministry of housing during 1996-97, the Maltzahn's farmhouse has been allowed to become derelict. The ministry had taken the roof off it. The roof was just strewn around the front yard, destroying the garden, and now all that is left is the walls and the chimney.

Recently the Department of Planning and Housing decided to go to the Civil and Administrative Tribunal to gain a demolition order on the walls and chimney of the Maltzahn's farmhouse. Regrettably, the tribunal decided in favour of the ministry for housing. This is a crying shame because in fact what the ministry for housing did when they built the dwellings was to build residences that were architecturally sensitive to the Maltzahn's farmhouse building. The significance of course of Maltzahn's farmhouse is that it is slightly different to the other bluestone buildings that have survived. It had symmetrically located groups of three windows on either side of a central door, and at the turn of the century the walls were rendered and painted white. It was in use up until the late 1980s.

Fortunately, upon the request of the City of Whittlesea the Minister for Planning and Local Government, Robert MacLellan, has intervened. Hopefully, through his good graces, the Department of Infrastructure and bodies like Heritage Victoria, some agreement may come about to save what is a very important part of the Westgarthtown historical precinct.

In talking about the precinct, we should not only talk about the buildings but also talk about the people who inhabited the area through such books as Westgarthtown by Robert Wuchatsch and other oral histories that have been collated. Recently, the City of Whittlesea used the German classes of the Mill Park Secondary College to put together some oral histories of survivors of the original families.

The point we should learn is that throughout history there has been a degree of tension over and a degree of questioning of the tolerance with which Australia has welcomed migrants from all over the world. At the time of the Great War, the loyalty of these immigrants from Germany was questioned. Many of them had been here for 40 or 50 years and had made a great contribution to the efforts that Australia was making to the British war effort. Many of the families sent sons to the front, many of the families actually contributed to the patriotic funds, but always they were open to innuendo and rumour. Always they got a clean bill of health.

For instance, when William Zimmer, a carter of nightsoil from the Broadmeadows camp, which was nearby, was the victim of many scurrilous complaints, the local constable, Constable Woodhouse, was required to investigate each complaint and finally got sick of it all and said:

I have made careful enquiries and I have been unable to find anything that would tend to prove that he was disloyal. I am sorry to say that these people who are only too ready to spread reports are the last to give information to the police. Zimmer bears a good character in the district.
Robert Wuchatsch, in the conclusion to his book, described his life at school as follows:

As with the Germans before them, life for today's immigrants has not always been free of difficulty. As a pupil attending Thomastown Primary School during the late 1950s I vividly recall the insults and ridicule heaped upon immigrant children not conforming to contemporary Australian standards—those with unusual clothing, names, accents and lunches, or parents who were either unable to speak English or who worked long hours to establish themselves. One of the greatest migrant crimes I recall was the growing of vegetables in front gardens . . .

Fortunately, times have changed at Thomastown and Lalor. Today the residents, both old and new Australians, have moved towards a working understanding of each other's cultures and values, if not an embracement of them.

I would really be grieving if that was not the case. I would really be grieving if in multicultural Australia those diversities were not welcome and if they were not welcomed with open arms to ensure that Australia develops from strength to strength as a multicultural society.
